smell_analysis.justification: No empty diagrams were found; each page that presents a clearly labeled diagram (package, use case, activity, class, state, or database-style class) contains visible elements.

On the use case diagram 'Autode halduse funktsionaalne allsüsteem (Muuda)' (page 3), the use case 'Vaata kõiki ootel või mitteaktiivseid autosid' appears without a direct association line to any actor and is only connected via 'include' relations, which does not count as actor association under this rule.
No use case diagram shows two or more use cases with names that clearly describe the same activity and are associated with the same actor; the use case names on pages 2 and 3 are distinct.
In the package diagram on page 1, the listed elements within each package appear to have unique primary names; no repeated primary element names in the same package are clearly visible.

The database-style diagrams (pages 14-19) do not explicitly show two or more tables storing redundant copies of the same data value without a foreign key connecting them; no unambiguous denormalization is visible.

Use case naming form appears consistent within the use case diagrams: the visible ovals on pages 2 and 3 start with active verbs such as 'Tuvasta', 'Vaata', 'Registreeri', 'Lõpeta', 'Muuda', 'Aktiveeri', and 'Unusta'.

In the state diagram 'Auto seisundidiagramm' (page 9), all named states shown (e.g., Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Unustatud, Lõpetatud) have visible incoming paths from the initial state or other states; no unreachable state is clearly indicated.

In the activity diagram 'Auto lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm' (page 4), each visible action appears connected by control flow from 'Algus' through decisions to subsequent actions and/or 'Lõpp'; no action is clearly unreachable.

Across the class diagrams (pages 5-13), association lines that are visible appear to have multiplicity labels where applicable, and the database diagrams use standard FK-style connectors that are exempt; no clear UML-style relationship between two elements lacking multiplicity indicators at both ends is unambiguously visible.

No single diagram clearly displays 10 or more central elements of the specified types. The use case diagrams show fewer than 10 use cases (pages 2 and 3), the state diagram shows fewer than 10 states (page 9), and the class/database diagrams on individual pages appear below this threshold.

No single class or table on any one class/database diagram is shown with 6 or more distinct visible relationship lines; for example, the 'Auto' class/table connections on the relevant pages appear below this count.
No relationship is shown with a distance that is explicitly and unambiguously more than twice the average distance between elements on the same diagram; no clear outlier layout is visible.

All visible use case names (pages 2 and 3) and activity actions (page 4) appear to start with active verbs such as 'Tuvasta', 'Vaata', 'Registreeri', 'Lõpeta', 'Muuda', 'Aktiveeri', 'Unusta', 'Otsi', and 'Vali'.
No class, table, attribute/column, or use case name with 3 or fewer characters is clearly visible. Common names like 'Isik', 'Auto', and 'Riik' exceed this length.
Visible class names appear to start with uppercase letters and are not clearly plural (e.g., Isik, Töötaja, Klient, Auto, Klassifikaator). No explicit violation is visible.

Attribute and column names shown in the class and database-style diagrams appear to start with lowercase letters (e.g., e_meil, eesnimi, isikukood, nimetus, mudel, vin_kood), with no clear uppercase-starting attribute/column name visible.

Database table names shown on the database-style diagrams appear singular (e.g., Isik, Kasutajakonto, Klient, Auto, Auto_mark, Riik). No clearly plural table name that represents a singular domain object is visible.

No class, table, or attribute names visibly use type-indicating prefixes like 'tbl_' or 'uc_'. The visible prefixes related to keys or indexes (e.g., PK_, FK_, pfK_, IXFK_) are explicitly allowed under this rule.
